intro: Vaccinium phillyreoides, commonly known as the narrowleaf huckleberry, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes many acid-loving plants such as blueberries and cranberries. The plant typically reaches heights of 30–60 centimeters and produces small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. Its leaves are narrow and dark green, often covered in a fine layer of white wax. The plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal forests and mountainous regions.
